title: Fraud and Friendship; or the orphan and the foundling of the King's printing-house. An Edinburgh tale. By the author of “Jessie Melville,” etc. [David Pae.]
author: Pae, David
snippet: All our Edinburgh readers know where Blair Street is—that itis a short and somewhat steep street, joining Hunter Square withthe Cowgate. They will also know that in this street is situatedthat large, well-built building, called " the King's House."

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Once or twice I thought that Morton appeared less hopeful,but the real change was as sudden as it was effectual. Hehad ventured forth from his mean lodging in Blair Street onesunny forenoon, and was quietly slipping round the Tron to ashop in the High Street, when Altryde and Nell turned gaily upfrom the North Bridge, arm in arm, as if going to the Castleon a pleasure stroll. Morton would as soon have expected thesun to drop at his feet, and he staggered back almost fainting.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: While he had been giving out bills one day at the shop door,a man who had been carelessly looking in at one of thewindows approached the shop door, and pretended to try thetexture ofthe cloth of an over-coat there displayed. Then, whileSlogan's back was turned, he tugged down the coat, darted into an entry leading down to Blair Street, and disappeared. Slogan did not run well, as the want of the arm interfered insome way with his balance, but he nevertheless managed toscramble and fall down the stair after the thief, and witha desperate spurt made up to him at the foot of the street.

author: Pae, David
snippet: In this buildingalone could the Scriptures be printed, and from nowhere else inScotland could they be issued. Hence, on the title-page of alloldish Bibles we see the names, " Sir David Hunter Blair and M.T. Bruce, Printers to the King's most Excellent Majesty;" and weare inclined to think that the street in which the building standstakes its name of Blair Street from the father of the baronetwho held the monopoly.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective

snippet: He went down the High Street to the public-house at whichhe had been robbed, and then wandered down to St Mary'sWynd, round by the Cowgate, and up Blair Street, and so hecontinued to march, never moving far from the centre, tillnearly midnight. No one passed him without having theirface scrutinised keenly, and M'Nair had no fear in these shadylocalities, for he had nothing to lose, and strength enough tobattle half a dozen ordinary men.

snippet: She was rather tall, and graceful in her movements, thesepartaking in a great degree the dignity and maturity of her character. Hardly had she crossed the opening to Hunter Square,when a young man, who was coming up Blair Street, caught sightof her, and immediately quickened his steps. It was the slender youth we noticed in the King's House; and,now that we see him on the open street, his handsome form is seento greater advantage.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective

snippet: The street, cabstand, hurrying passengers, and everything outside was there,precisely as they had been left, but the box had vanished. They looked round in every direction, and even sprang wildlyalong to the head of Blair Street, but not a trace of the student'spossessions was to be seen. Not a soul was near, either, butan innocent-looking ragamuffin, who was diligently playing asolitary game of " bools " in the smooth gutter; and to him,in desperation, they addressed themselves.
